questions.text: All the following are features of infantile cortical hyperostosis, except which?

options.label: A
options.text: Pathology reveals evidence of inflammation and haemorrhage

options.label: B
options.text: Common in infants under six months of age

options.label: C
options.text: Soft tissue swelling over the diaphysis of long bones, particularly clavicle and ulna

options.label: D
options.text: The onset is usually acute module 15

questions.correct_answer: A. Pathology reveals evidence of inflammation and haemorrhage
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pathology reveals evidence of inflammation and haemorrhage New bone formation is seen in infantile cortical hyperostosis, with no evidence of inflammation and hemorrhage.

Highyeild:

table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} CAFFEY'S DISEASE Infantile cortical hyperostosis (Caffey's Disease) A. It is a self-limiting disorder characterised by soft tissue swelling, rapid subperiosteal new bone formation, cortical thickening of underlying bones, fever and irritability. B. Classically, the disease's onset occurs before the 5th month of life, with a resolution by three years of age. C. In sporadic cases, the mandible is the most common site of involvement, presenting as jaw tumor or swelling, i.e., firm, tender without heat or redness. D. Presence of raised ESR & alkaline phosphatase & anemia mimic infection E. Tibia> ulna is most frequently involved in the familial form. Presentation ● Seen in infants and young children. ● It starts during the ﬁrst few months of life with painful swelling over the tubular bones and the mandible. ● Etiology: idiopathic Clinical features: Child presents with ● Fever and irritability, ● Refusing to move the affected limb ● Swelling is present with no local signs of inﬂammation. ESR, elevated. X-rays ● Characteristically show periosteal new bone formation resulting in thickening of the affected bone. Other causes of hyperostosis ● Osteomyelitis ● Scurvy. Treatment ● Antibiotics are sometimes employed. CAFFEY’S DISEASE

Hyperparathyroidism Brown tumors are giant cell lesions caused by abnormal bone metabolism in hyperparathyroidism . Increased circulating PTH aggravates osteoclastic bone absorption, then leads to diffuse osteopenia, fractures or multiple circumscribed lytic lesions.

Highyeild:

Brown Tumor Brown tumors are tumors of bone that arise in settings of excess osteoclast activity, such as hyperparathyroidism, and consist of fibrous tissue, woven bone and supporting vasculature but no matrix. They are radiolucent on x-ray. The osteoclasts consume the trabecular bone that osteoblasts lay down. This front of reparative bone deposition, followed by additional resorption, can expand beyond the usual shape of the bone, involving the periosteum and causing bone pain. The characteristic brown colouration results from hemosiderin deposition into the osteolytic cysts. Also typical of giant cell tumours of the bone.
